日本語



A translation team based in Birmingham, UK, we specialise in a small number of languages (English, French, German and Japanese) of which we are native speakers or which we have studied for decades. Our mission is to help you connect with suppliers, distributors and customers in countries where these languages are spoken.

In addition to language capability we offer expertise in desktop publishing, making us a one-stop shop for firms importing from or exporting to Austria, France, Germany, Japan, Switzerland and many other countries. Does your company require product flyers for the Japanese market (for example)? Just send us your English text and a sketch of the layout, and we can take care of the whole process of creating a professional-looking PDF for you.

You'll find details of our services and prices below, along with samples of our work and testimonials from our satisfied customers.

Translation

日本語


French/German→English

In GDP terms, Germany and France rank as the world's 4th- and 7th-largest economies respectively, and trade between the UK and the French- and German-speaking countries of Europe (which also include Austria, Belgium, Liechtenstein, Monaco and Switzerland) was valued at around GB£280 billion in 2016. Whatever changes in the UK's relationship with the EU occur in the next few years, these countries will surely continue to be major trading partners of the UK. That means operator's manuals, contracts, technical papers, marketing literature, product information, corporate websites etc. etc. will all need to be translated into English!

We have completed translations from German and French into English for dozens of companies in sectors including rail technology, HVAC, industrial machinery, construction vehicles, forestry, management training, leisure and tourism, and more. If it's English→French or German translation that you need, feel free to get in touch, as we can place your project with trusted colleagues in Europe whom we have known for many years.




English→Japanese & Japanese→English

With the 2020 Tokyo Olympics on the horizon, all eyes will soon be fixed on the "Land of the Rising Sun". The world's third largest economy in GDP terms, Japan has a trade relationship with the UK valued at almost GB£29 billion in 2016, and Japanese firms are currently looking for UK business partners in semiconductors, clothing, industrial sensors, video games, robotics, medical devices, artifical intelligence and a host of other areas We can help you break through the barriers to communication with suppliers, distributors and customers in Japan!

We have completed translation projects in a huge range of fields – just about everything from pharmaceutical marketing and firefighter training to toxic waste disposal and home audio systems. All of our translations into Japanese are written by a Japanese native speaker and then checked by an English native speaker, while all of our translations from Japanese to English are written by an English native speaker and then checked by a Japanese native speaker. This strict quality control process allows us to offer translations that are complete, accurate and natural-sounding.

Desktop Publishing and Other Services

日本語



Desktop Publishing (DTP)

Do you need a Japanese version of a product marketing flyer? Well, Japanese has strict typographical rules (about the characters that can be at the end of a line, for example); so, for a professional look, it's essential to send typesetting work in Japanese to people who know the language. Just provide us with your English source files and we'll do the rest, translating your text and then using the world-class design tools in Adobe Creative Cloud to recreate your document in Japanese as a file ready to take to the printers or post on your company's website. Is there no English PDF available? No problem! All you need do is let us have your text and a sketch showing your desired layout, and we'll produce a draft PDF for your approval. We can also professionally typeset any existing text in Japanese, English, French or German.




Editing and Writing

Good writing takes time and a calm environment where you can focus on the smallest details – luxuries that people running a business may not have! Are you rushing to put together reports or presentations between meetings/at airports/in your lunchbreak? That's probably why you missed those typos. . . . Let us take the headache out of business writing for you by checking spelling and grammar, suggesting more concise and effective wording, formatting bibliographical references and taking care of all those other editing tasks for which there just aren't enough hours in your busy day. We can also write copy in English or Japanese to your specifications and even create reports from source materials that you provide.*

*Students please note: we DO NOT accept requests to ghostwrite school/college coursework!

How We Work

日本語



As professional translators, we never write in a foreign language! Michael always translates from French/German/Japanese into his native language (English), never the other way round. Likewise, Yoshiko only ever translates in one direction – from her second language (English) into Japanese. This policy is in line with translation industry best practice.

We often deal with source (original) documents containing technical terms too specialised for inclusion in any dictionary. This means that, for a translation into English (for example), we have to look for relevant English-language technical literature. If this isn't available on the public Internet, we can use other resources. Unlike many other freelance translators, we have access to the online holdings of a university library, allowing us to consult the latest journal articles on all fields of science and technology. Reading specialist literature takes time, but it's the only way to find the terms that specialists use.

If we're translating the home page of your company's website, then, an addition to conveying meanings accurately, we'll be seeking to craft our version so as to strike exactly the right tone, persuading readers that your company is one that they want to do business with. Accordingly we'll spend a good deal of time polishing our translation before we send it to you. A translation that sounds as if it was the original is what we aim for.

By the way, should we need background information or an explanation of something in your source document, we'll have questions for you. Please bear with us – we're just fanatical about getting things right.

Pricing, Charges & Payment

日本語



How do we price translation jobs?

Unfortunately, we can't quote a price based only on the number of pages in a document. (Google Translators can do that, but that's because for them all jobs take about the same amount of time!) For human translators like us, the number of words (in English/French/German) or characters (in Japanese) is one of the major factors in how long a job takes, and we can't tell how many words/characters there are in a document just from the number of pages.

Therefore, like other reputable translation providers, we need to see your document and count the number of words/characters it contains before we can quote you a price. If your document is a non-editable PDF, we may still be able to create an editable file – using optical character recognition software – and then do the word/character count from that.

Materials like product catalogues tend to contain a large number of repeated words. If you have such materials to be translated, we can take the repetitions into account in order to offer you a fair price. We'll use a professional software package (SDL Trados Studio) to quantify the repetitions and calculate a reasonable discount on the per-word/character price for you.

We're sorry that we can't say precisely (to within an hour or so) how long a translation project will take, because translation isn't like mass-producing standardised parts. Every job is different, and we can make only a rough guess of the time required, so please note that all delivery times quoted are provisional.


How much do we charge?

Prices below are in GB £. Please contact us if you would like us to quote a price in JP ¥, US $ or EU €.

Service Price Remarks
English → Japanese translation GB £0.XX per English word For translation plus checking by a second translator
Japanese → English translation GB £0.XX per Japanese character For translation plus checking by a second translator
French → English translation GB £0.XX per French word For translation only (checking by a second translator available for an extra charge)
German → English translation GB £0.XX per German word For translation only (checking by a second translator available for an extra charge)
Checking English → Japanese translation GB £0.XX per English word
English → French translation Please ask for a price quotation
English → German translation Please ask for a price quotation
Certifying a translation GB £5 See below for definition of "certifying"*
Correcting English text written by Japanese native speaker G B£0.XX per English word
Desktop publishing Depends on difficulty Please ask for a price quotation
English copywriting, report writing GB £XX per 500 words
Japanese copywriting, report writing GB £XX per YYY characters
Printing and mailing hard copies GB £5 Minimum charge
Hourly rate GB £20
Minimum invoice amount GB £10

*"Certifying" means that we sign, date and stamp a translation, state our qualifications as translators, and affirm that we have, to the best of our knowledge and belief, translated your document accurately and completely.


How can I pay?

For projects with an invoice value under £75/¥10,500/$95/€8, we can accept payment by

  • electronic transfer to our bank account in Japan
  • electronic transfer to our bank account in the UK

(See our invoice for further details.)


How do we protect you against fraud?

For projects with an invoice value over £75/¥10,500/$95/€85, we'll ask you to work with us via peopleperhour.com, a well-known online platform. This service is absolutely free of charge for you as a customer. We'll send you a link so that you can register for an account there, and you'll be asked to deposit the price of the job with the platform when you place your order. Your money will not be released to us until we have delivered the work to you, and your credit card details will never be disclosed to us. This arrangement means complete peace of mind for us and you.

About Us

日本語



Michael

Michael (the "M" in M&Y Translations) is a native speaker of UK English. Since starting French at the age of nine, he has spent most of his life as a language learner, teacher or translator. After studying German and French at university, he took the opportunity to learn Japanese during a 15-year stay in Japan. His qualifications include a 1st-class BA degree in German and French from the University of Reading (UK), a Postgraduate Certificate in Teaching English as a Foreign Language, a Certificate of Proficiency in Japanese, a Postgraduate Certificate in Child Speech and Language Difficulties from the University of Sheffield (2013) and a Certificate of Higher Studies in Communication from Birmingham City University (UK). Of all the hundreds of translation projects that he has completed since founding M&Y Translations in 2011, his most memorable one is a collection of letters from French musicians serving at the front during World War 1 (French→English). You can read this on line at https://www.rncm.ac.uk/paris-manchester-1918/.


Yoshiko

Yoshiko (the "Y" in our team) hails from Nagoya, Japan and has lived in the UK since 2010. Her qualifications include a BA degree in Archeology from Nanzan University (Japan), a Cambridge First Certificate in English, an 875 score in TOEIC, a Japan Translation Federation Certificate and a DTP Director Certificate. Among the numerous projects that she has undertaken for M&Y Translations, her favourites are the translation of Mr King's Incredible Journey, an illustrated children's book by David Du Plessis (English→Japanese), and desktop publishing work on Space to Breathe: Thoughts from a Japanese Garden by Koji Takeuchi (Maitreya) and Pauline Bell. She has a strong interest in British history and is a member of the Richard III Society.
